head.title: Wind and Fast Greens Get the Better of the Best

hedline.hl1: Wind and Fast Greens Get the Better of the Best
hedline.hl2: Wind and Fast Greens Get the Better of the Best

block.p: On a postcard-pretty morning at an old converted nursery, a retired professional golfer walked to the first tee at Augusta National Golf Club and announced that it was a beautiful day. Arnold Palmer reared back, smacked a drive on the screws, and faded into the background of the Masters, leaving 96 players to give their own assessment of a tournament that teases and tempts them so.
''Hard as I've ever played it,'' said Chris DiMarco, playing in his seventh Masters.
Augusta National battered almost everyone and nearly toppled defending Masters champion Phil Mickelson on the first day of play.

On a postcard-pretty morning at an old converted nursery, a retired professional golfer walked to the first tee at Augusta National Golf Club and announced that it was a beautiful day. Arnold Palmer reared back, smacked a drive on the screws, and faded into the background of the Masters, leaving 96 players to give their own assessment of a tournament that teases and tempts them so.
''Hard as I've ever played it,'' said Chris DiMarco, playing in his seventh Masters.
''It's a bitter golf course,'' said Troy Matteson, playing in his first.

At the end of an unforgiving first round Thursday that made the best players in the world wobble, Brett Wetterich and Justin Rose each finished at three-under-par 69 to share a one-shot lead over David Toms and David Howell.

Rich Beem was among five golfers two shots back. Davis Love III headlined a group of five players who trailed by three shots. And Tiger Woods, after making bogey on each of his last two holes, trailed by four shots after a round of one-over-par 73.

With swirling winds and speedy greens, Augusta National battered almost everyone and nearly toppled Phil Mickelson. He opened with a bogey on his way to a front-nine 40, and shot a 76 to stand seven strokes off the lead in his pursuit to join Jack Nicklaus, Nick Faldo and Woods as back-to-back Masters champions.
Ernie Els, who wants a Masters title more than any other, shot a 78. Paul Casey of England, a Ryder Cup standout, shot a 79.

After being slowed by rainy conditions in recent years, Augusta National played hard and fast for a change, with greens that turned potential birdies into bogeys. Balls bounded over mounds, sped over humps, and generally dashed in any direction they pleased. Only two players -- Beem and Howell -- posted eagles on the day.
''The greens have been firm before, but not like this,'' said Nick O'Hern, who shot a 76. ''A few of the holes, I could not read the greens.''
Woods, chasing his third consecutive victory at a major, pieced together steady play with a few wild tee shots.
As his round neared dusk, he missed the fairway on Nos. 17 and 18 to the right, leading to back-to-back bogeys and a frown.

If it was not the pollen getting him down -- Woods rubbed his nose constantly during the round -- it was his finicky driver. ''I've got to go figure a few things out,'' he said. ''I threw away a good round of golf.''

Woods, who has never broken 70 in the first round of the Masters, made par on his first six holes before adding a bogey on the seventh. He jumped on the leader board with birdies on the par-5 13th and 15th holes, only to hit drives into pine needles on the final two.
He found only 7 of Augusta National's 14 fairways, which are among the widest in major championship golf.
''I just wasn't driving it well,'' he said. ''I wasn't sweeping it very good.''

Despite his disappointment, Woods's score was topped by only 14 players. The only player immune to the tough conditions was the 77-year-old Palmer, who greeted the day wearing a light-blue sweater, dark trousers, and wielding a golf bag filled with clubs.

After declining a ceremonial role in recent years, Palmer accepted Augusta National's invitation to become the tournament's honorary starter, who is responsible for hitting a tee shot on the first hole and kindly stepping aside.
In front of thousands who wrapped themselves around the tee, Palmer stepped up to his ball with a driver and briefly considered making his own rules.
Why not sneak in a quick 18 holes?
''Maybe I'll just keep going,'' he said as he waggled his driver.
He hit a soft draw that traveled more than 200 yards before it settled into the left rough. The crowd erupted in applause, Palmer gave way, and the other golfers held on tight.
Matteson, a Masters rookie, chunked his approach shot on No. 9 so badly that his ball traveled only halfway to the green. The crowd surrounding the hole let out a gasp. It was one of many on the day.
''You do this on this golf course,'' said Matteson, who shot a 79. ''It's pretty painful. I hit a lot of bad golf shots. It's going to make for a tough week.''

Rose was the only golfer who did not make a bogey Thursday. Three years ago, he led the Masters through two rounds before a third-round 81 dropped him from the leader board. He said he had trouble sitting on the lead because he could not find ways to occupy his time before the round.
On Friday, Rose is scheduled to tee off at 2:14 p.m.

''I'll probably watch a little bit of 'Little Britain' DVDs, Ali G DVDs, just stuff to occupy your mind, really,'' he said. ''You have to forget about it, reset the dial, and treat tomorrow as a clean slate.''
GOLF
